case_title: Dr. K. Rajmohan v. Kerala Agricultural University

questions_and_answers.question: What was the claim made by Dr. K. Rajmohan against Kerala Agricultural University?
questions_and_answers.answer: The claim made by Dr. K. Rajmohan against Kerala Agricultural University was for stepping up of his pay in tune with the pay of one Dr. B. Balkrishnan, who was allegedly a teacher junior to him, with effect from 01.01.1986.

questions_and_answers.question: Who were the parties involved in the writ appeal against the judgment of High Court of Kerala?
questions_and_answers.answer: The appellants in the writ appeal were Kerala Agricultural University (KAU) and The Comptroller, KAU, while the respondent/petitioner was Dr. K. Rajmohan who was a retired professor of College of Agriculture, Velayani, residing in Vellakadavu P.O., Thiruvananthapuram. Adv. Sri. Robson Paul, SC, Kerala Agricultural University (KAU) represented the appellants, and Adv. P.V. Jayachandran represented the respondent/petitioner.

questions_and_answers.question: According to the judgment, what was the question that the learned Single Judge did not consider in the writ petition?
questions_and_answers.answer: According to the judgment, the learned Single Judge did not consider the question whether the claim raised by the petitioner for parity of pay was sustainable.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the decision of the Writ Appeal No. 167 of 2023, and what is the judgment of the Court with respect to the writ petition?
questions_and_answers.answer: In the Writ Appeal No. 167 of 2023, the Court allowed the appeal, set aside the impugned judgment, and dismissed the writ petition. The Court rejected the petitioner's claim for pay parity as unsustainable.

questions_and_answers.question: Which judgment became final in regards to the University extending the benefit to certain teachers?
questions_and_answers.answer: The judgment in W.P.(C) No.10496 of 2006 and connected cases became final, and based on that judgment, the University extended the benefit of non-cadre promotion to the post of Associate Professor in the UGC scale on completion of ten years of service in the University to the petitioner of this case, as well as to three other teachers.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the argument put forward by the learned Standing Counsel for the University in response to the petitioner's claim?
questions_and_answers.answer: The learned Standing Counsel for the University contended mainly that the claim raised by the petitioner on the premise that Dr. B. Balakrishnan and two other teachers referred to in the writ petition are juniors to him is unsustainable as they are seniors to him going by the dates on which they joined the service of the University as Junior Assistant Professors.

questions_and_answers.question: Which order allows for the appointment of an Advisory Council by Kerala Agricultural University?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Kerala Agricultural University (Officers) Service Rules, 1970 contains an order that allows for the appointment of an Advisory Council by Kerala Agricultural University.

questions_and_answers.question: In what context is the claim made that a senior cannot be paid a lesser salary than their junior?
questions_and_answers.answer: The claim that a senior cannot be paid a lesser salary than their junior is made in the context of giving equal pay for equal work to prevent discrimination based on seniority. The Doctrine of Equal Pay for Equal Work has been regarded as an essential feature of modern democratic societies that seek to ensure social and economic justice for all their citizens.

questions_and_answers.question: Which cases did the petitioner refer to in the writ petition as being relevant to this case?
questions_and_answers.answer: The petitioner referred to the judgment dated 26.05.2015 in W.P.(C) No.16252 of 2012 as being relevant to this case. According to the petitioner, this Court accepted an identical claim in an identical case.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the background of Dr. Elizabeth K. Syriac, and what was her case about?
questions_and_answers.answer: Dr. Elizabeth K. Syriac was an Assistant Professor in the Kerala Agricultural University who got the benefit of two advance increments in terms of the 1996 UGC Regulations on acquiring Ph.D. degree. Her junior, Dr. L.Girija Devi who acquired Ph.D. while 2006 UGC Regulations were in force, got the benefit of three advance increments. Syriac had filed a writ petition, which the High Court allowed, granting her the same advance increments as Devi received. However, the Supreme Court reversed the judgment of the High Court, holding that no parity between them could be ensured as they got their PhD degree in two different streams and also the Regulations which were in force at the time they acquired their degree were not the same.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the premise on which the petitioner made their claim for stepping up of their pay?
questions_and_answers.answer: The premise on which the petitioner made their claim for stepping up of their pay was that, in terms of the pay revision order of the State Government viz, G.O.(P) No.515/85/Fin. dated 16.09.1985, a Professor is entitled to a higher pay on completion of 10 years of service in the University.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the main argument posed by the University in response to the judgment in W.P.(C) No.10496 of 2006 and connected cases?
questions_and_answers.answer: The main argument posed by the University in response to the judgment in W.P.(C) No.10496 of 2006 and connected cases was that the said judgment had been given only with respect to the the facts and circumstances of W.P.(C) No.10496 of 2006 and connected cases, and that it could not be applied generally to other cases.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision made by the Apex Court in Union of India v. E.S. Soundara Rajan, (1980) 3 SCC 125?
questions_and_answers.answer: The decision made by the Apex Court in Union of India v. E.S. Soundara Rajan, (1980) 3 SCC 125 was that there cannot be a case of discrimination merely because of the fortuitous circumstances arising on account of the peculiarity of the facts of a particular case. Fact situations arising in a case may create advantages or disadvantages for one group or the other although in the earlier stages, they were more or less alike.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the major principle that was applied in deciding the claim of pay parity in the present case?
questions_and_answers.answer: The major principle that was applied in deciding the claim of pay parity in the present case was the Doctrine of Equal Pay for Equal Work. The court noted that there cannot be a case of discrimination merely because of the fortuitous circumstances arising out of some peculiar developments or situations create advantages or disadvantages for one group or the other although in the earlier stages they were, more or less, alike. If one class has not been singled out for special treatment, the mere circumstances of advantages accruing to one or the other cannot result in breach of Article 14 of the Constitution.

questions_and_answers.question: According to the judgment, what were the facts of the case dealt with by the Division Bench in Elizabeth K. Syriac, and how do they differ from the present case?
questions_and_answers.answer: According to the judgment, the facts of the case dealt with by the Division Bench in Elizabeth K. Syriac were that Syriac got two advance increments and her junior, Dr.L.Girija Devi, who acquired Ph.D while 2006 UGC Regulations were in force, got three advance increments. While Syriac filed a writ petition, which the High Court allowed, granting her the same advance increments as Devi, the Supreme Court held that no parity between them could be ensured, as they got their PhD degree in two different streams and the Regulations which were in force at the time they acquired their degree were not the same. The Court opined that the facts of the present case are neither identical nor similar to the facts of the Elizabeth K. Syriac case.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the statement of law made by the Apex Court in Gurcharan Singh Grewal?
questions_and_answers.answer: The statement of law made by the Apex Court in Gurcharan Singh Grewal is that a senior cannot be paid a lesser salary than his junior, which has to be understood in the light of the principles laid down by the Apex Court in E.S. Soundara Rajan, G. Sreenivasa Rao and Debasish Mukherjee, of which Debasish Mukherjee is a later decision.

questions_and_answers.question: What conditions must be met for a senior to claim stepping up of pay compared to a junior?
questions_and_answers.answer: For claiming stepping up of pay of the senior, the service particulars of the junior and senior should be identical in all respects; and the anomaly must be one arising on account of fixation of the pay of the junior as per his entitlement.

questions_and_answers.question: What difference does the legal context make with respect to Equal Pay for Equal Work?
questions_and_answers.answer: The context of the law behind Equal Pay for Equal Work is to provide equal pay and to prevent discrimination based on seniority. Therefore, a senior employee receiving a lower pay than a junior employee may create an anomaly; however, this anomaly may exist based on specific circumstances, and there may be legit reasons for the same.

questions_and_answers.question: According to the High Court in the present case, can a senior claim pay parity merely based on junior employees receiving a higher pay?
questions_and_answers.answer: No, according to the High Court in the present case, a senior cannot claim pay parity merely based on junior employees receiving a higher pay as their seniority has no relevance to their entitlement to a higher pay. Therefore, a senior only has the right to claim pay parity if there is substantive justification for the same within the specific legal framework.

questions_and_answers.question: What are the cases that the Court relied on while rejecting the petitioners' claim of parity?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Court relied on various cases where the nature of the anomaly existed because of certain specific legal provisions or a particular situation. These cases included Union of India v. E.S. Soundara Rajan, (1980) 3 SCC 125, Gurcharan Singh Grewal, and Indian Airlines Ltd. v. Prabha D. Kishore, (2011) 9 SCC 497.

questions_and_answers.question: What are the requirements for senior employees to claim pay parity?
questions_and_answers.answer: For senior employees to claim pay parity, the service particulars of the senior and junior employees must be identical, there must be an anomaly that arises in the junior employees' pay fixation compared to their entitlement, and the anomaly must be such that the differentia is based on intelligible criteria that has a rational nexus with the object sought to be achieved.

questions_and_answers.answer: The implication of Regulation 12(3) of the National Legal Services Authority (Lok Adalats) Regulations, 2009 on the scope of judicial review under Article 226 of the Constitution of India is that any regulation made invoking the statutory provision cannot enlarge or expand the scope and width of Article 226 of the Constitution of India. Nevertheless, the regulation provides for a right to approach the court to challenge procedural violation but such violation cannot be the basis to hold that it would vitiate the award. case_title: State of Kerala vs Dr. A. Augustine

questions_and_answers.question: Who filed the writ petition in this case?
questions_and_answers.answer: Dr. A. Augustine filed the writ petition in this case.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the short point that arises for consideration in this appeal?
questions_and_answers.answer: The short point that arises for consideration in this appeal is whether the petitioner has made out a case of violation of fundamental right guaranteed under Article 14 of the Constitution in the context of the decision taken by the State Government to extend HRA with reference to the location of the office of the employees concerned.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision taken by the State Government which is under question?
questions_and_answers.answer: The decision taken by the State Government which is under question is related to the extension of House Rent Allowance (HRA) to Dr. A. Augustine, who had been working at the Kerala Agricultural University (the University) Headquarters at Vellanikkara within the geographical limits of Madakkathara Panchayath, which is located adjoining the boundary of Thrissur Corporation.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision of the High Court in W.P.(C) No. 21677 of 2012?
questions_and_answers.answer: The decision of the High Court in W.P.(C) No. 21677 of 2012 was in favour of the petitioner. The High Court held that there was a violation of Article 14 of the Constitution and directed the State Government to extend the HRA to the petitioner.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision of the Kerala High Court in this appeal?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Kerala High Court dismissed the writ appeal filed by the State of Kerala and held that the decision of the State Government to refuse HRA to the petitioner cannot be said to be for any unreasonable discrimination against the petitioner and that the writ petition was rightly dismissed by the learned single judge of this court.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision taken by the State of Karnataka with respect to HRA and CCA payable to State Government employees and the peripheral area falling within eight kilometers from the boundaries of Bangalore City Corporation?
questions_and_answers.answer: The State of Karnataka provided that the peripheral area falling within eight kilometers from the boundaries of Bangalore City Corporation would be treated as part of the Bangalore City Corporation for the purpose of grant of HRA and CCA payable to State Government employees.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the view of the Apex Court in Mangalore University Non-Teaching Employees' Assn., (2002) 3 SCC 302, with respect to the alteration of the entitlement for HRA and CCA of State Government employees?
questions_and_answers.answer: The view of the Apex Court in Mangalore University Non-Teaching Employees' Assn., (2002) 3 SCC 302, is that the State Government is entitled to alter unilaterally the conditions of service of its employees, including the entitlement for HRA and CCA as long as such an action is in conformity with the legal and constitutional provisions, and the impugned orders of the State Government do not fall foul of Article 14 merely on account of the same reason.

questions_and_answers.question: Was the decision of the Apex Court in the Mangalore University Non-Teaching Employees' Assn., case in conformity with the provisions of Article 14 of the Constitution of India?
questions_and_answers.answer: Yes, the decision of the Apex Court in the Mangalore University Non-Teaching Employees' Assn., case was in conformity with the provisions of Article 14 of the Constitution of India as it held that the State Government is entitled to alter unilaterally the conditions of service of its employees, including the entitlement for HRA and CCA as long as such an action is in conformity with the legal and constitutional provisions, and the impugned orders of the State Government do not fall foul of Article 14 merely on account of the same reason.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the argument made by the petitioner in the present case to establish infringement of the fundamental right guaranteed under Article 14 of the Constitution?
questions_and_answers.answer: The petitioner in the present case argued that the denial of HRA to the petitioner while extending the same to the employees working in other establishments of the University situated within the limits of Thrissur Corporation amounted to infringement of the fundamental right guaranteed under Article 14 of the Constitution. The petitioner contended that the Headquarters of the University is situated at Vellanikkara within the geographical limits of Madakkathara Panchayath, which is located adjoining the boundary of Thrissur Corporation.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the reasoning of the Court for their decision in this appeal?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Court reasoned that the employees of the University working in establishments situated within the limits of Thrissur Corporation and employees working in establishments of the University situated outside the limits of the Thrissur Corporation form two different classes and there is no illegality in treating them differently. The Court also held that the petitioner cannot have any case as the State Government has nothing to do with the same and for the geographical segregation it has only adopted the segregation made by the Government of India. As the petitioner did not have any case that the non-inclusion of Madakkathara Panchayat is an instance of inequality arising from lack of proper classification or that there is an element of arbitrariness in specifying the places to be brought under Thrissur Corporation, the decision of the State Government to refuse HRA cannot be said to be for any unreasonable discrimination against the petitioner.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the view of the Court with respect to the complaint based on Article 14 of the Constitution in the context of the decision taken by the State Government to extend HRA with reference to the location of the office of the employees concerned?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Court held that while formulating such rules, it is difficult to envisage all situations and facts peculiar to a few places here and there and a legislative provision or an executive order of general application does not become unconstitutional merely because, in its actual application, it turns out to be disadvantageous or inequitable to certain individuals or a small section of people.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the main issue in the present appeal?
questions_and_answers.answer: The main issue in the present appeal is to determine whether the petitioner has made out a case of violation of fundamental right guaranteed under Article 14 of the Constitution in the context of the decision taken by the State Government to extend HRA with reference to the location of the office of the employees concerned.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the result of the present appeal?
questions_and_answers.answer: The result of the present appeal was that the writ appeal filed by the State of Kerala was dismissed by the Kerala High Court.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision of the Division Bench of the Karnataka High Court in the State of Karnataka v. Mangalore University Non-Teaching Employees' Assn. case?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Division Bench of the Karnataka High Court in the State of Karnataka v. Mangalore University Non-Teaching Employees' Assn. case accepted the case of the employees of the Mangalore University and held that the orders issued by the State Government in this regard were discriminatory.

questions_and_answers.question: What were the benefits given to the establishments situated within eight kilometers from the periphery of the Bangalore City Corporation by the State Government of Karnataka?
questions_and_answers.answer: The benefits given to the establishments situated within eight kilometers from the periphery of the Bangalore City Corporation by the State Government of Karnataka were HRA and CCA.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the view of the Apex Court in the Mangalore University Non-Teaching Employees' Assn. case with respect to a legislative provision or an executive order of general application which turns out to be disadvantageous or inequitable to certain individuals or a small section of people?
questions_and_answers.answer: The view of the Apex Court in the Mangalore University Non-Teaching Employees' Assn. case with respect to a legislative provision or an executive order of general application which turns out to be disadvantageous or inequitable to certain individuals or a small section of people is that such a provision or order does not become unconstitutional merely because, in its actual application, it turns out to be disadvantageous or inequitable to certain individuals or a small section of people.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision of the Kerala High Court with respect to the decision of the State Government to refuse HRA to the petitioner?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Kerala High Court held that the decision of the State Government to refuse HRA to the petitioner cannot be said to be for any unreasonable discrimination against the petitioner.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the contention of the petitioner in the present case?
questions_and_answers.answer: The contention of the petitioner in the present case was that inasmuch as Madakkathara Panchayat, within whose limits the Headquarters of the University is situated, is a Panchayat located adjoining the boundary of Thrissur Corporation and inasmuch as the employees working in other establishments of the University situated within the limits of Thrissur Corporation are being disbursed HRA as applicable to employees in establishments situated in Thrissur Corporation, there is no justification for denying the benefit of HRA as applicable to Thrissur Corporation to the employees working in the Headquarters of the University.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the view of the Court with respect to the benefit of HRA as applicable to Thrissur Corporation to the employees working in the Headquarters of the University?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Court held that the refusal of the benefit of HRA as applicable to Thrissur Corporation to the employees working in the Headquarters of the University cannot be said to be for any unreasonable discrimination against the petitioner.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the view of the Court with respect to the petition of the petitioner regarding the infringement of fundamental right guaranteed under Article 14 of the Constitution?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Court held that the petition of the petitioner regarding the infringement of fundamental right guaranteed under Article 14 of the Constitution fails.

case_title: Raveendran Pillai S vs State of Kerala

questions_and_answers.question: What is the case number and title of the judgment document?
questions_and_answers.answer: The case number is WA NO. 944 of 2022 and the title is Raveendran Pillai S vs State of Kerala.

questions_and_answers.question: When was the judgment document issued by the court?
questions_and_answers.answer: The judgment document was issued on January 5, 2023.

questions_and_answers.question: Who were the appellants and respondents in the writ petition, WP(C) 18584/2021?
questions_and_answers.answer: The appellants/respondents 1, 2, 4 & 5 in the writ petition were the State of Kerala, the District Educational Officer, the Accountant General, and the Secretary to Government Finance Department. The petitioner/respondent 1 & 3 in the writ petition was Raveendran Pillai S, while respondent 2 was the manager of Karavaram Vocational Higher Secondary School.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the issue raised in the writ petition?
questions_and_answers.answer: The petitioner argued that his interruptions and service rendered in leave vacancies should be reckoned as qualifying service for pension. He claimed that his qualifying service for pension would be 30 years 11 months and 14 days if these periods were also reckoned, while the verification report limiting his qualifying service to 23 years was challenged in the writ petition.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the ruling of the court on the issue of service rendered in leave vacancies for pension?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court ruled that a person appointed in a leave vacancy does not obtain any lien to the post, and therefore, not entitled to pensionary benefits unless there is any specific order under Rule 11 of Part III KSR which enables the Government to allow the service rendered by an employee to count for pension. Since the petitioner did not have such an order for service rendered in leave vacancies, the court held that he was not entitled to count the said service for pension.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the ruling of the court on reckoning interruptions in service as qualifying service for pension?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court observed that government decision No. 8 beneath Rule 14E of Part III KSR, which previously allowed counting of interruptions in service as qualifying service for pension in certain cases, has been deleted. Since Rule 31 of Part III KSR dealing with interruptions in service was also substituted with effect from 27.11.2019, the court held that the aforesaid argument of the petitioner that interruptions in his service should be counted was without any substance.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the main argument of the petitioner regarding reckoning service rendered in leave vacancies for pension?
questions_and_answers.answer: The petitioner argued that since he had been granted increments and time-bound higher grades, reckoning the services rendered by him in leave vacancies, it cannot be said that the said service cannot be reckoned as qualifying service for pension.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the main argument of the government in the writ petition?
questions_and_answers.answer: The government mainly contended that in light of the amendments made to Rule 14E(a) of Part III of the Kerala Service Rules (KSR), the interruptions and the service rendered by the petitioner in leave vacancies are not liable to be reckoned as qualifying service for pension.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the purpose of use of Form No.2B of Appendix X in Part III KSR?
questions_and_answers.answer: Form No.2B of Appendix X in Part III KSR is used for forwarding the pension papers of the petitioner. It shows particulars of service, last pay and pension of the retired Government Servant.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the final judgment of the court in the writ appeal?
questions_and_answers.answer: The writ appeal was allowed, the impugned judgment was set aside, and the writ petition was dismissed.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the qualification service of Raveendran Pillai as shown in the verification report issued by the office of the Accountant General?
questions_and_answers.answer: The qualifying service of the petitioner was shown only as 23 years, excluding the interruptions and the service rendered in leave vacancies.

questions_and_answers.question: What were the Government orders referred to in the court judgment that dealt with amendments made to Rule 14E(a) of Part III of the Kerala Service Rules?
questions_and_answers.answer: The amendments made to Rule 14E(a) of Part III of the Kerala Service Rules (KSR) were referred to in terms of G.O.(P) No.128/2018/Fin dated 10.08.2018 and G.O.(MS) No.401/2019/Fin dated 28.10.2019.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the impact of the change made to Rule 31 of Part III KSR, and when was it effected?
questions_and_answers.answer: The change made to Rule 31 of Part III KSR with respect to interruptions in service was that interruptions in service will not count for pension, subject to certain provisions. This change was effected in terms of S.R.O.No.938/2019 with effect from 27.11.2019.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the main contention of the counsel for the petitioner on counting service rendered in leave vacancies for pension, and how did the court respond?
questions_and_answers.answer: The counsel for the petitioner contended that since the petitioner has been granted increments and time-bound higher grades, and the services rendered by him in leave vacancies are shown as qualifying service in Ext.P6 statement, the said service should be counted for pension. However, the court observed that even if service rendered in leave vacancies was shown as qualifying service in the statement, it does not entitle the petitioner to count the same since there was no specific order under Rule 11 of Part III KSR which enables the Government to allow the service rendered by an employee to count for pension.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the significance of Rule 11 of Part I KSR in the case?
questions_and_answers.answer: Rule 11 of Part I KSR provided that an officer's claim to pension is regulated by the rules in Part III KSR. This rule was relevant in the case since the petitioner was claiming pensionary benefits under Part III KSR.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the main argument of the government regarding interruptions in service for pension?
questions_and_answers.answer: The government argued that the petitioner's service was lawful only during the period of the appointment, and there was no suggestion that the termination of petitioner's appointment was illegal. Thus, the petitioner's service was rightly shown as only 23 years for the purpose of calculating qualifying service for pension.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the judgment of the Kerala High Court in W.P.(C) No.29356 of 2016?
questions_and_answers.answer: In the judgment in W.P.(C) No.29356 of 2016, the Kerala High Court held that a Government employee is not entitled to pensionary benefits for the provisional service unless there is any specific order under Rule 11 of Part III KSR which enables the Government to allow the service rendered by an employee to count for pension. The court held that insofar as teachers of aided colleges are concerned, the lien attached to their order of appointment is only limited to the period of appointment, and the service rendered by them in leave vacancies cannot be taken into account for pensionary benefits.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision of the Division Bench of the Kerala High Court in State of Kerala v. Sumayamma George, 2022 (1) KLT 426?
questions_and_answers.answer: In State of Kerala v. Sumayamma George, 2022 (1) KLT 426, the Division Bench of the Kerala High Court held that going by the scheme of Kerala Service Rules (KSR), it is the occupancy of a post together with a lien thereto either limited or absolute that entitles the lien holder to the pensionary benefits attached to that post. It was held that a person appointed in a leave vacancy does not obtain any lien to the post, he merely officiates or occupies that post till the original incumbent returns after leave. Therefore, the service rendered by teachers in leave vacancies cannot be counted for the purpose of computation of their pensionary benefits.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the observation of the court on relying on the statement, Ext.P6, to count service rendered in leave vacancies for pension?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court observed that Ext.P6 is only a statement forwarded from the School in terms of the provisions contained in Part III KSR so as to enable the petitioner to claim pension. Merely for the reason that a statement contrary to Rule has been made in such a statement, the petitioner cannot take advantage of the same.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the difference between a substantive vacancy and a leave vacancy, as per the court's observation?
questions_and_answers.answer: As per the court's observation, a person appointed in a substantive vacancy obtains a lien to the post, which entitles the lien holder to the pensionary benefits attached to that post. However, a person appointed in a leave vacancy does not obtain any lien to the post, since he merely officiates or occupies that post till the original incumbent returns after leave.

questions_and_answers.question: What were the grounds on which the judgment in W.P.(C) No.29356 of 2016 was challenged in appeal, and what was the decision of the Division Bench on those grounds?
questions_and_answers.answer: The judgment in W.P.(C) No.29356 of 2016 was challenged in appeal, among others, on the ground that insofar as the service rendered in broken spells including leave vacancies are reckoned for grant of increments, it is arbitrary to hold that the said service is not liable to be reckoned for pension. However, the Division Bench which dealt with the appeal affirmed the decision of the learned Single Judge in Shameer Ali E v. Deputy Director of Collegiate Education, Kollam and Others, 2018 (3) KHC 361, repelling the ground aforesaid. It is seen that later Rule 14E(b) of Part III KSR itself was under challenge in a batch of writ petitions before this court to the extent it stipulated that only regular service rendered by teachers in private aided colleges, prior to the regular service rendered by them in the aided/Government colleges, would be reckoned for the purpose of computation of their pensionary benefits.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the case about?
questions_and_answers.answer: The case is about whether RERA has ousted the jurisdiction of the Permanent Lok Adalat in disputes relating to housing and real estate services.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the prayer of the petitioner in the writ petition?
questions_and_answers.answer: The prayer of the petitioner in the writ petition was to quash Exhibit P3 Order of the 1st respondent dismissing Exhibit P1 complaint and to direct the 1st respondent to proceed with Exhibit P1 complaint and to pass an award on merit after hearing the parties, within a time-frame fixed by the Hon'ble Court.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the jurisdiction of Permanent Lok Adalat?
questions_and_answers.answer: The jurisdiction of Permanent Lok Adalat is to entertain the complaints filed by the parties and arrive at a settlement, if both parties agree, and to pass an award under Section 22C(7) of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987.

questions_and_answers.question: Has RERA ousted the jurisdiction of Permanent Lok Adalat constituted under the Legal Services Authorities Act 1987?
questions_and_answers.answer: No, RERA has not ousted the jurisdiction of Permanent Lok Adalat constituted under the Legal Services Authorities Act 1987.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the definition of "housing and real estate service" under Legal Services Authorities Act 1987?
questions_and_answers.answer: "Housing and real estate service" is defined under Section 22A of the Legal Services Authorities Act 1987 as a "public utility service".

questions_and_answers.question: What is the definition of "public utility service" under the Legal Services Authorities Act 1987?
questions_and_answers.answer: "Public utility service" is defined under Section 22A of the Legal Services Authorities Act 1987 as any service which is essential to the life of the community and includes among other things banking, insurance, and transport services.

questions_and_answers.question: What does Section 79 of RERA say?
questions_and_answers.answer: Section 79 of RERA says that no civil court shall have jurisdiction to entertain any suit or proceeding in respect of any matter which the Authority, the Adjudicating Officer, or the Appellate Tribunal is empowered by or under this Act to determine, and no injunction shall be granted by any court or other authority in respect of any action taken or to be taken in pursuance of any power conferred by or under this Act.

questions_and_answers.question: Does Permanent Lok Adalat come under the definition of civil court as per Section 79 of RERA?
questions_and_answers.answer: No, Permanent Lok Adalat does not come under the definition of civil court as per Section 79 of RERA.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the court decide in this case?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court decided that the jurisdiction of Permanent Lok Adalat is not ousted by the advent of RERA in dealing with matters relating to housing and real estate services.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the final order passed by the court in this case?
questions_and_answers.answer: The final order passed by the court is that the appeal is allowed, and the impugned judgment is set aside. The matter is remanded to the Lok Adalat for fresh consideration and disposal.

questions_and_answers.question: What does Section 25 of the Legal Services Authorities Act 1987 say?
questions_and_answers.answer: Section 25 of the Legal Services Authorities Act 1987 says that the provisions of the Act shall have an overriding effect over any other law for the time being in force.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the main objective of the Legal Services Authorities Act 1987?
questions_and_answers.answer: The main objective of the Legal Services Authorities Act 1987 is to provide free and competent legal services to the weaker sections of the society to ensure that opportunities for securing justice are not denied to any citizen by reasons of economic or other disabilities.

case_title: M/S. LISIE MEDICAL INSTITUTIONS vs THE STATE OF KERALA

questions_and_answers.question: What is W.A.NO.1386 of 2016?
questions_and_answers.answer: W.A.NO.1386 of 2016 is an appeal filed by M/s. Lisie Medical Institutions against the order by the Government demanding building tax for their hospital building constructed in 2013.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the Kerala Building Tax Act?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Kerala Building Tax Act is an act that governs the levy of tax on buildings constructed in Kerala. It contains provisions allowing for exemption of building tax for buildings used principally for religious, charitable or educational purposes.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the decision of the Supreme Court in Civil Appeal No.6799 of 2017?
questions_and_answers.answer: In Civil Appeal No.6799 of 2017, a three Judge Bench of the Supreme Court doubted the correctness of an earlier two Judge bench decision in SH Medical Centre Hospital v. State of Kerala and referred the matter to a three Judge bench. The matter was remanded to the High Court of Kerala, resulting in W.A.NO.1386 of 2016.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the brief outcome of the Lisie Medical Institutions vs State of Kerala case?
questions_and_answers.answer: The brief outcome of the Lisie Medical Institutions vs State of Kerala case was that, after much judicial deliberation, the High Court of Kerala found that the hospital owned by M/s. Lisie Medical Institutions would not qualify for the exemption in Kerala Building Tax Act for “buildings used principally for religious, charitable or educational purposes”.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the purpose of Section 3(2) of the Kerala Building Tax Act?
questions_and_answers.answer: The purpose of Section 3(2) of the Kerala Building Tax Act is to refer any question that arises regarding whether a building qualifies for exemption in terms of Section 3(1) of the Act to the Government which is then obliged to decide after giving the interested parties an opportunity to present their case.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the definition of charitable purpose according to Explanation 1 to Section 3(1) of the Kerala Building Tax Act?
questions_and_answers.answer: According to Explanation 1 to Section 3(1) of the Kerala Building Tax Act, charitable purpose includes and is not confined to the relief of the poor and free medical relief.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the finding of the Government regarding the exemption of the building constructed by M/s. Lisie Medical Institutions in 2013?
questions_and_answers.answer: According to Ext.P9 order dated 17.03.2016, the building constructed by M/s. Lisie Medical Institutions in 2013 would not qualify for the exemption contemplated under Section 3(1) of the Act for 'buildings used principally for religious, charitable or educational purposes' when read with Explanation 1 to the said provision.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the role of the Government in deciding whether a building qualifies for exemption under Section 3(2) of the Kerala Building Tax Act?
questions_and_answers.answer: The role of the Government in deciding whether a building qualifies for exemption under Section 3(2) of the Kerala Building Tax Act is to decide the question referred to it after giving the interested parties an opportunity to present their case. The decision of the Government under Section 3(2) shall be final and shall not be called in question in any court of law according to Section 3(3) of the Act.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the decision of Lisie Medical Institutions v. State of Kerala 1?
questions_and_answers.answer: In Lisie Medical Institutions v. State of Kerala 1, a two Judge bench found, inter alia, that the phrase charitable purpose in Explanation 1 goes to indicate that charitable purpose includes and is, therefore, not confined to the relief of the poor and free medical relief.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the role of courts in the interpretation of exemption provisions under tax statutes?
questions_and_answers.answer: The role of courts in the interpretation of exemption provisions under tax statutes is to construe the statute according to the object sought to be achieved by the provision and in accord with such object. A liberal and strict construction of an exemption provision are to be invoked at different stages of interpreting it.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision of the Full Bench of the Kerala High Court in Unity Hospital 4?
questions_and_answers.answer: In Unity Hospital 4, a Full Bench of the Kerala High Court held that in the specific context of providing medical relief, it is only free medical relief that will qualify as a charitable purpose for the purposes of the exemption under the statutory provision.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision of the Supreme Court in SH Medical Centre Hospital v. State of Kerala 2?
questions_and_answers.answer: In SH Medical Centre Hospital v. State of Kerala 2, a two Judge bench of the Supreme Court maintained the view that only free medical relief will qualify as a charitable purpose for the purposes of the exemption under the statutory provision.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision of the two Judge bench in Mother Superior Adoration Convent3?
questions_and_answers.answer: In Mother Superior Adoration Convent3, a two Judge bench of the Supreme Court affirmed an earlier Full Bench decision of the Kerala High Court that took into consideration the scope of the exemption under Section 3 of the Kerala Building Tax Act.

questions_and_answers.question: How should the exemption provision under Section 3(1)(b) of the Kerala Building Tax Act be interpreted?
questions_and_answers.answer: The exemption provision under Section 3(1)(b) of the Kerala Building Tax Act must be interpreted according to its beneficial purpose and given full effect to. A literal formalistic interpretation of the statutory provision should be avoided. The court must ask what is the object sought to be achieved by the provision and construe the statute in accord with such object.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the view of the court regarding the amount of medical relief provided by M/s. Lisie Medical Institutions in the building in question?
questions_and_answers.answer: Even if we were to treat the exemption under Section 3(1)(b) as available to a hospital that provides a substantial amount of free medical relief to the poor or the needy, the figures shown in the order of the government that was impugned in the writ petition reveal that the hospital had expended only 4.23% and 4.56% of its funds towards provision of free medical relief. Thus, it could not get the benefit of a liberal interpretation of the statutory provision.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the difference between the decisions in SH Medical Centre Hospital v. State of Kerala 2 and Mother Superior Adoration Convent3?
questions_and_answers.answer: The difference between the decisions in SH Medical Centre Hospital v. State of Kerala 2 and Mother Superior Adoration Convent3 is that a two Judge bench of the Supreme Court in SH Medical Centre Hospital v. State of Kerala 2 found that only free medical relief will qualify as a charitable purpose, while a Full Bench of the Kerala High Court in Mother Superior Adoration Convent3 found that the concept of free service is provided only in the Explanation to the Section and that medical relief providing medical treatment at concessional rates does not qualify.

questions_and_answers.question: What are the legal principles relating to the interpretation of exemption provisions?
questions_and_answers.answer: The legal principles relating to the interpretation of exemption provisions are that they are to be construed strictly on the normal principle of construction or interpretation of statutes, either because of legislative intention or on economic justification of inequitable burden or progressive approach of fiscal provisions intended to augment state revenue. But once an exemption becomes applicable, no rule or principle requires it to be construed strictly. Liberal and strict construction of an exemption provision are to be invoked at different stages of interpreting it.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the extent of free medical relief provided by M/s. Lisie Medical Institutions in the building in question?
questions_and_answers.answer: According to the figures shown in the order of the government that was impugned in the writ petition, the hospital had expended only 4.23% and 4.56% of its funds towards provision of free medical relief. This is well below the extent needed to qualify for the exemption under Section 3(1)(b) of the Kerala Building Tax Act according to the legal principles applied by the court.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the significance of Explanation 1 to Section 3(1) of the Kerala Building Tax Act?
questions_and_answers.answer: Explanation 1 to Section 3(1) of the Kerala Building Tax Act provides the definition of charitable purpose, which includes and is not confined to the relief of the poor and free medical relief. The court found that “the Explanation goes to indicate that charitable purpose includes and is, therefore, not confined to the relief of the poor and free medical relief”.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision of the Division Bench that dismissed the writ appeal filed by M/s. Lisie Medical Institutions?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Division Bench that dismissed the writ appeal filed by M/s. Lisie Medical Institutions followed the same judgment of the Supreme Court as the High Court of Kerala, finding that the hospital did not qualify for the exemption under Section 3(1) of the Kerala Building Tax Act.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision of the three Judge Benches of the Supreme Court regarding what can qualify as a charitable purpose in the context of providing medical relief?
questions_and_answers.answer: The three Judge Benches of the Supreme Court held that it is not only free medical relief but other kinds of charitable activities that would also qualify as charitable purposes under the Kerala Building Tax Act, but used the legally applied principles to find that in the case of the hospital owned by M/s. Lisie Medical Institutions, only free medical relief would qualify as a charitable purpose for exemption purposes under the Kerala Building Tax Act.

questions_and_answers.question: What was Section 13(2) of the Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Security Interest Act, 2002 (SARFAESI Act) about?
