questions_and_answers.answer: The judgment in Writ Petition No.23832 of 2023 dismissed the writ petition filed by the appellant, which was challenging the same sale notice dated 22.06.2023 issued by the respondent Bank, as evidenced by Ext.P2 in the present writ appeal.

questions_and_answers.question: What were the arguments made by the learned counsel for the appellant?
questions_and_answers.answer: The learned counsel for the appellant relied on the payment of Rs.1,50,000/- made by the appellant on 27.07.2023, as evidenced by Annexure-1 pay-in-slip, towards his liability in the financial assistance availed from the respondent Bank. The learned counsel submitted that the learned Single Judge went wrong in dismissing the writ petition without considering the financial difficulty faced by the appellant.

questions_and_answers.question: What is a writ of mandamus?
questions_and_answers.answer: A writ of mandamus is a direction or order of a court given to a government official or a public authority to perform their duties correctly and according to law.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the meaning of SARFAESI Act?
questions_and_answers.answer: SARFAESI stands for Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Security Interest Act, 2002. It is an act of Indian parliament that allows banks and financial institutions to auction commercial and residential properties of defaulters to recover their loans.

case_title: Shalini Thomas vs. State of Kerala

questions_and_answers.question: What is the background of the case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: Mrs. Shalini Thomas, Assistant Professor in Economics in BCM college in Kottayam, Kerala, was appointed on 23.07.2012. The management did not pay the salary of the petitioner from the month of March, 2015, which led to the filing of WP(C) 5575/2015.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the subject matter of the appeal in case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: The subject matter of the appeal was whether a teacher in a private college, appointed against a non-existing post, was entitled to salary and allowances in view of the approval granted by the University and whether it would be a personal liability of the persons who carried out selection, appointment, and approval of the appointments.

questions_and_answers.question: Who were the appellants in case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: In case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022, the State of Kerala, represented by the Additional Chief Secretary to Government, the Director of Collegiate Education, and the Deputy Director of Collegiate Education, Kottayam were the appellants.

questions_and_answers.question: Who were the respondents in case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: In case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022, Smt. Shalini Thomas, Assistant Professor in Economics, BCM College, and the Manager, BCM College for Women, Kottayam, and the Mahatma Gandhi University, represented by its Registrar, Priyadarshini Hills were the respondents.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the judgment in WP(C) 5575/2015 before the appeal in case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: In WP(C) 5575/2015, the learned Single Judge allowed the writ petition, stating that since the appointment of the petitioner has been approved by the University, the Directorate of Collegiate Education cannot raise any objection to the disbursement of salary to the petitioner.

questions_and_answers.question: Who gave the judgment in case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: The judgment in case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022 was given by the benches of P.B.Suresh Kumar, J, and C.S.Sudha, J, on 4th January 2023.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the argument made by the learned Senior Counsel for the petitioner in case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: The learned Senior Counsel for the petitioner argued that insofar as the appointment of the petitioner has been approved by the University, her salary cannot be denied.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the argument made by the learned Government Pleader in case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: The learned Government Pleader argued that the workload of the subject Economics in the College was only 40 hours, and the permissible number of posts was only 2, as per the norm that was in force at the relevant time.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the reasoning of the court in case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022 in relation to the appointment of the petitioner?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court reasoned that the appointment of the petitioner in the academic year 2012-13 could only be regarded as one made against a non-existing post as existing posts were already fully occupied before her appointment. Therefore, the petitioner was not entitled to receive a salary and allowances for a post that did not exist.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision of the court in case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court dismissed the appeal made by the State of Kerala and affirmed the judgment of the learned Single Judge in WP(C) No. 5575 of 2015. The court held that the appointment of the petitioner was against a non-existing post, and hence she is not entitled to salary and allowances for such an appointment.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the court observe concerning the personal liability of those who carried out the selection, appointment, and approval of an appointment against a non-existing post?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court observed in case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022 that such an appointment could only be regarded as one made against a non-existing post. The court also remarked that if the appointment is found to be not in order, the person or persons who carried out the selection, appointment, and approval of appointment against non-existing posts will have to meet the debt from their own funds.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the court observe about the responsibility of the State Government to pay the salary of teachers appointed by the University?
questions_and_answers.answer: In the judgment of case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022, the court observed that it is obligatory on the part of the government to release salary due to the teachers whose appointments are approved by the University. However, the government has no obligation to disburse salary if appointments are made by the aided management when there is no sanctioned post.

questions_and_answers.question: Can a teacher in a private college be appointed against a non-existing post?
questions_and_answers.answer: In case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022, the court remarked that a teacher in a private college cannot be appointed against a non-existing post and is not entitled to salary and allowances for such an appointment.

questions_and_answers.question: Who was the learned Senior Counsel for the petitioner in case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: The learned Senior Counsel for the petitioner in case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022 is not named in the document.

questions_and_answers.question: Who was the learned Government Pleader in case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: The learned Government Pleader in case WA NO. 1419 OF 2022 was Sri.A.J.Varghese.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the workload of the subject Economics in BCM College in Kottayam, according to the learned Government Pleader in case WA NO. 1419 of 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: According to the learned Government Pleader in case WA NO. 1419 of 2022, the workload of the subject Economics in BCM College in Kottayam was only 40 hours, and the permissible number of posts was only 2, as per the norm that was in force at the relevant time.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the statement jointly prepared by the Director of Collegiate Education and the Principal of the College regarding the workload of Economics department in BCM College in Kottayam?
questions_and_answers.answer: As per Ext.P8 statement, the workload of the Economics department in BCM College was revised to 40 hours, and the permissible number of posts for 40 hours of workload was only two, going by the norm prevailing then.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the court examine before giving its judgment in case WA NO. 1419 of 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: Before giving its judgment in case WA NO. 1419 of 2022, the court examined the workload of the subject Economics in the College, the arguments of the learned Government Pleader, the submissions of the University Standing Counsel, and the relevant statutory provisions and judgments.

questions_and_answers.question: Who allowed the writ petition in case WP(C) No.5575 of 2015?
questions_and_answers.answer: The learned Single Judge allowed the writ petition in case WP(C) No.5575 of 2015.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the relevance of the decision of this Court in Cherian Mathew vs. Principal, S.B. College, Changanassery, to the case WA NO. 1419 of 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: The relevance of the decision of this Court in Cherian Mathew vs. Principal, S.B. College, Changanassery, to the case WA NO. 1419 of 2022 was that when a teacher is appointed in a private college in terms of the provisions contained in the concerned University Statute, his salary has to be paid by the government, provided the appointment was approved by the University.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the legal principle that obligates the government to pay salary to teachers whose appointments are approved by the University?
questions_and_answers.answer: The legal principle that obligates the government to pay salary to teachers whose appointments are approved by the University is that once the University accords sanction of a post and grants approval, it is obligatory for the State Government to pay the salary of such a teacher.

case_title: Dr. Sushama S vs The State of Kerala and Ors.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the judgment delivered in W.A No. 1460 of 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: The judgment delivered in W.A No. 1460 of 2022 by the Kerala High Court held that the appointment of the petitioner against the leave vacancy could not be regarded as an appointment made against a substantive vacancy.

questions_and_answers.question: Who were the appellants and respondents in W.P.(C) No.19394 of 2019?
questions_and_answers.answer: The appellants and respondents in W.P.(C) No.19394 of 2019 were the State of Kerala and other respective state officials (respondents 1-5), and Dr. Sushama S (petitioner and 6th respondent).

questions_and_answers.question: Who were the learned counsel in W.A No. 1460 of 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: The learned counsel in W.A No. 1460 of 2022 was the learned Government Pleader and counsel for the petitioner, Santosh Mathew, and P. Gopal.

questions_and_answers.question: Who was the petitioner in W.A No. 1460 of 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: The petitioner in W.A No. 1460 of 2022 was Dr. Sushama S, an associate professor (retired) at NSS college.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the main issue in W.A No. 1460 of 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: The main issue in W.A No. 1460 of 2022 was whether the service rendered by Dr. Sushama S in the leave vacancy preceding her absorption without break in the regular establishment of the college could qualify for pensionary benefits.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the eligibility criterion for pension as per Part III KSR?
questions_and_answers.answer: As per Part III KSR, the eligibility criterion for pension was regular full-time services of teachers of private colleges in government colleges.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the role of statute 2(i) of the 1979 statute in W.A 1460 of 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: The meaning of Substantive vacancy was defined in Statute 2(i) of the 1979 Statute in W.A No. 1460 of 2022.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision passed by the learned single judge in the writ petition filed under No.19394 of 2019?
questions_and_answers.answer: In the writ petition filed under No.19394 of 2019, the learned single judge quashed Ext.P9 verification report to the extent to which it was challenged as also Ext.P14 communication and directed the official respondents to issue fresh orders sanctioning pensionary benefits to Dr. Sushama S.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the government's contention regarding the entitlement of pension in W.A No. 1460 of 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: In W.A No. 1460 of 2022, the government's contention was that the entitlement of pension for teachers of private colleges is regulated by the Rules contained in Part III KSR as amended from time to time.

questions_and_answers.question: Why did the court decide that Dr. Sushama S was not entitled to the pension?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court decided that Dr. Sushama S was not entitled to the pension because the appointment of the petitioner against the leave vacancy could not be regarded as an appointment made against a substantive vacancy and service rendered by Dr. Sushama S in the leave vacancy preceding her absorption without break in the regular establishment could not qualify for pensionary benefits.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the Division Bench's decision in State of Kerala v. Sumayamma George, 2022 (1) KLT 426, dealing with the claim of prior service in aided private colleges?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Division Bench in State of Kerala v. Sumayamma George, 2022 (1) KLT 426 held that going by the scheme of KSR, it is the occupancy of a post together with a lien thereto either limited or absolute that entitles the lien holder to the pensionary benefits attached to that post.

questions_and_answers.question: What effect did the court's ruling in the W.A 1460 of 2022 have on earlier cases involving prior service in aided private colleges?
questions_and_answers.answer: The ruling in the W.A 1460 of 2022 is an affirmation of earlier judgments in identical cases of prior service in aided private colleges. It also prohibits counting the service in leave vacancies for grant of pension contra to Rule 4 of Part III KSR which provides that no leave period shall count towards pension.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the rule controlling pensions of employees in W.A. 1460 of 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: Rule 1(a) of part III KSR regulated pensions of all employees to whom KSR applies in W.A. 1460 of 2022.

questions_and_answers.question: What were the specific reasons cited by the learned counsel for the petitioner in W.A. no. 1460 of 2022 why Dr. Sushama S's service should qualify for pension benefits
questions_and_answers.answer: The petitioners submitted that if the initial appointment of Dr. Sushama S is treated as an appointment against a substantive vacancy, the service rendered by Dr. Sushama S pursuant to the said appointment is liable to be treated as regular full-time service as provided for in Rule 14E(b)(i) of Part III KSR.

questions_and_answers.question: State Rule 4 of Part III KSR.
questions_and_answers.answer: As per Rule 4 of Part III KSR, no leave period shall count towards pension, except extraordinary leave granted on medical certificate up to a period of not more than one year or any leave or extension of leave granted on loss of pay to officiate under time-scale or provisionally or during the period of training.

questions_and_answers.question: According to Rule 14E(b) of Part III KSR, what service does qualify for pensionary benefits in private colleges-related employees?
questions_and_answers.answer: As per Rule 14E(b) of Part III KSR, only regular full-time service will qualify for pensionary benefits in private colleges related employees.

questions_and_answers.question: What does mutatis mutandis mean in Rule 5 of Part III KSR?
questions_and_answers.answer: In Rule 5 of Part III KSR mutatis mutandis means the same thing happening in respect of a similar thing.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the case summary of W.A. No. 1460 of 2022?
questions_and_answers.answer: W.A. No. 1460 of 2022 dealt with the entitlement of pension for teachers of private colleges in government colleges and the court's interpretation of Statute 2(i) of the 1979 Statutes and rule 14E(b)(i) of part III KSR.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the definition of substantive vacancy in Statute 2(i) of the 1979 Statutes?
questions_and_answers.answer: Statute 2(i) of the 1979 Statutes defined substantive vacancy as a permanent vacancy to which an appointment may be made in accordance with the provisions of the Statutes.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the Government Order no. 113/16/Fin state?
questions_and_answers.answer: Government Order no. 113/16/Fin clarified that regular/broken spells including leave vacancies of aided college service of regular aided college staff shall not be counted for pension with full-time regular aided college service in a writ petition filed under No.29356 of 2016 and connected cases.

case_title: State of Kerala vs Durgadas

questions_and_answers.question: Who were the Petitioners in OP(KAT) No. 267 of 2021?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Petitioners in OP(KAT) No. 267 of 2021 were the State of Kerala, represented by the Principal Secretary to Government, Home (SSB) Department, the Additional Director General of Police, Intelligence, Police Head Quarters, and the Commandant, India Reserve Battalion, Thrissur.

questions_and_answers.question: Who were the Respondents in OP(KAT) No. 267 of 2021?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Respondents in OP(KAT) No. 267 of 2021 were Durgadas and the Kerala Public Service Commission, represented by its Secretary.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the order delivered in OP(KAT) No. 267 of 2021?
questions_and_answers.answer: In OP(KAT) No. 267 of 2021, the Court directed the Screening Committee to reconsider Durgadas's appointment and ordered the Respondents to comply with it by issuing an appointment letter to Durgadas within four weeks from the date of receipt of the copy of the order. There shall be no order as to costs.

questions_and_answers.question: What was argued by the Additional Advocate General in OP(KAT) No. 267 of 2021?
questions_and_answers.answer: In OP(KAT) No. 267 of 2021, the Additional Advocate General argued that the scope of judicial review was limited and that the subjective element of satisfaction as to the character and integrity cannot be substituted by a different view of the Tribunal. According to him, the Tribunal went beyond its jurisdiction and interfered with the autonomy and choice made by the employer/Government.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the meaning of "honourable acquittal" in the context of character and antecedents?
questions_and_answers.answer: In the context of character and antecedents, the phrase "honourable acquittal" means that the findings in the acquittal are material or relevant in an assessment of the character and antecedents. In a criminal case, there may be findings reflecting character and may be short of a criminal offence for want of elements constituting the offence. Still, that may be valid or relevant.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the outcome in Anil Kumar A. v. State of Kerala and Others [2012 (2) KHC 257]?
questions_and_answers.answer: In Anil Kumar A. v. State of Kerala and Others [2012 (2) KHC 257], the Court opined that the question whether one is suitable in the police force will have to be considered by the Department notwithstanding his acquittal, and the Department is even free to terminate such a person if his character and antecedents are found to be bad.

questions_and_answers.question: How is the term "satisfaction" used in OP(KAT) No. 267 of 2021?
questions_and_answers.answer: In OP(KAT) No. 267 of 2021, the term "satisfaction" is used to refer to the subjective element of satisfaction as to the character and integrity of a candidate for the appointment in the police force. The Additional Advocate General argued that the subjective element cannot be substituted by a different view of the Tribunal.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the significance of the certificate of medical fitness?
questions_and_answers.answer: The certificate of medical fitness is significant in considering the character and antecedents of a candidate for appointment in the police force. A candidate must satisfy the medical standards laid down by Rule 25 of the Kerala Police Subordinate Officers and Police Constables (Appointment and Conditions of Service) Rules, 2015.

questions_and_answers.question: What are the legal principles applied by the Court in evaluating character and antecedents for appointment in the police force?
questions_and_answers.answer: The legal principles applied by the Court in evaluating character and antecedents for appointment in the police force are that the government objectively enquires character and antecedents to find whether such a person can be appointed in any post in such a service. In that process, the criminal case records, including civil cases, may be relevant if it reflects the character and antecedents of such a person. The scope of inquiry, in such a situation, is to find out whether the allegations and materials in criminal case qualifies him to occupy the office in the service or not.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the outcome in Pramod Singh Kirar v. State of M.P. [(2023) 1 SCC 423]?
questions_and_answers.answer: In Pramod Singh Kirar v. State of M.P. [(2023) 1 SCC 423], the Supreme Court held that from the judgment and order of acquittal passed by the trial court, it appears that there was a matrimonial dispute which ended in settlement and the original complainant did not support the case of the prosecution. Thus, it can be seen that the appellant did not face the prosecution for the other offences of IPC. Therefore, for whatever has happened, the character of the person is to be taken into account while considering him for appointment

questions_and_answers.question: What was at issue in OP(KAT) No. 267 of 2021?
questions_and_answers.answer: The issue in OP(KAT) No. 267 of 2021 was whether the Screening Committee was justified in rejecting the candidature of Durgadas, who faced trial in a criminal case, on the ground that his character and antecedents do not make him suitable for appointment in the service. The Tribunal quashed the Screening Committee's decision, and the State was aggrieved by the same.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the Court say about the role of the Tribunal in interfering with the Selection Committee's assessment?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Court held that the Tribunal cannot sit as an appellate authority to call for the personal records and constitute Selection Committee to undertake this exercise. This power is not given to the Tribunal, and it should be clearly understood that the assessment of the Selection Committee is not subject to appeal either before the Tribunal or by the courts. One has to give credit to the Selection Committee for making their assessment, and it is not subject to appeal.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the role of the Screening Committee in OP(KAT) No. 267 of 2021?
questions_and_answers.answer: The role of the Screening Committee in OP(KAT) No. 267 of 2021 was to assess the character and antecedents of the candidates for appointment in the service. The Committee considers the criminal case records, including civil cases, if it reflects the character and antecedents of the person. The scope of inquiry is to find out whether the allegations and materials in criminal cases qualify him to occupy the office in the service or not.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the Court say about the impact of a compromise or settlement on the consideration of the character and antecedents of a candidate?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Court held that the Screening Committee may decline to take cognizance of a compromise if it appears to be dubious. The Committee cannot be faulted for that. Compromises or settlements have to be encouraged to bring about a peaceful and amiable atmosphere in the society by according a quietus to disputes. They are also encouraged to reduce arrears of cases and save the litigants from the agony of pending litigation. However, these considerations cannot be brought in while considering the character and antecedents of a candidate for appointment in the service.

questions_and_answers.question: What was challenged in OA 2076/2020?
questions_and_answers.answer: In OA 2076/2020, Durgadas challenged the screening committee's rejection of his candidature for appointment in the service on the ground that his character and antecedents do not make him suitable for appointment in the service.

questions_and_answers.question: What happened in the case of Madhya Pradesh and Ors. v. Abhijit Singh Pawar [(2018) 18 SCC 733 : (AIR 2018 SC (Supp) 1493)]?
questions_and_answers.answer: In Madhya Pradesh and Ors. v. Abhijit Singh Pawar [(2018) 18 SCC 733 : (AIR 2018 SC (Supp) 1493)], the two-judge bench opined that even after the disclosure is made by a candidate, the employer would be well within his rights to consider the antecedent and suitability of the candidate.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the Additional Advocate General argue in Anil Kumar A. v. State of Kerala and Others [2012 (2) KHC 257]?
questions_and_answers.answer: In Anil Kumar A. v. State of Kerala and Others [2012 (2) KHC 257], the Additional Advocate General argued that the right to appoint a person in the police force was a highly regulated matter and that an acquittal and a discharge cannot be the determinative factors. The character antecedents of the petitioner have to pass meticulous scrutiny.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the Court say about compromises and settlements in OP(KAT) No. 267 of 2021?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Court held that the Screening Committee may decline to take cognizance of a compromise if it appears to be dubious. The Committee cannot be faulted for that. Compromises or settlements have to be encouraged to bring about a peaceful and amiable atmosphere in the society by according a quietus to disputes. They are also encouraged to reduce arrears of cases and save the litigants from the agony of pending litigation. However, these considerations cannot be brought in while considering the character and antecedents of a candidate for appointment in the service.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the Court say about the assessment of the Selection Committee in OP(KAT) No. 267 of 2021?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Court held that the assessment of the Selection Committee is not subject to appeal either before the Tribunal or by the courts. One has to give credit to the Selection Committee for making their assessment, and it is not subject to appeal. Taking the overall view of ACRs of the candidates, one may be held to be very good, and another may be held to be good. If this type of interference is permitted, then it would virtually amount that the Tribunals and the High Courts have started sitting as Selection Committee or act as an appellate authority over the selection.

questions_and_answers.question: What is Rule 25 of the Kerala Police Subordinate Officers and Police Constables (Appointment and Conditions of Service) Rules, 2015?
questions_and_answers.answer: Rule 25 of the Kerala Police Subordinate Officers and Police Constables (Appointment and Conditions of Service) Rules, 2015 states that a candidate for appointment in the police force must satisfy the medical standards laid down by the Rule. It also defines the medical standard of a candidate and the procedure for medical examination.

case_title: State of Kerala vs PV Kuryan

questions_and_answers.question: What is the case about?
questions_and_answers.answer: The case is about a driver who was suspended from the Kerala Police service for a criminal case against him, but was acquitted by the Appellate Court. The case was initiated against him on two sets of allegations: firstly, with reference to the criminal offence, and secondly, with reference to the illicit relationship with the first accused, Radha. The departmental proceedings were initiated against him and he was ordered to be removed from service, but this order was set aside by the Kerala Administrative Tribunal(‘Tribunal’) which was challenged in this appeal.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the dispute in the case?
questions_and_answers.answer: The main dispute in the case was whether a departmental inquiry proceeding could be initiated against a police officer who was acquitted of a criminal offence that was unrelated to the charges being investigated in the departmental proceedings. The State of Kerala argued that the accused was not honourably acquitted and hence, was liable for departmental proceedings while the respondent argued that since he had been acquitted of the criminal charge, the departmental proceedings should be dropped against him as well.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision of the Kerala High Court in the case?
questions_and_answers.answer: The final decision was in favor of the respondent. The Court held that in adherence to Section 101(8) of the Police Act, when a police servant is involved in a criminal case and he is acquitted from the criminal case, he cannot be proceeded against by the department on the same set of facts in the departmental proceeding. The Court also held that the Government is not supposed to enquire into the private affairs of a Government servant unless any manifest misconduct is expressed in such activities, warranting action.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the main argument of the learned Senior Government Pleader?
questions_and_answers.answer: The learned Senior Government Pleader's main argument was that the Tribunal committed a grave error in allowing the application as he was not honourably acquitted and the fact that he had an illicit relationship with the first accused lady reflecting poorly on the Police Department which could sustain an independent charge itself to justify the departmental proceedings and the penalty imposed.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the main argument of the learned counsel for the respondent?
questions_and_answers.answer: The learned counsel for the respondent argued that the departmental proceedings are on the same set of facts as alleged in the criminal case hence, on acquittal, the departmental proceedings would come to an end and no action could have been taken against the respondent. The counsel also argued that no court or authority had found that the respondent had an illicit relationship with the accused lady without any proceedings culminating in such finding. Hence, it is not open for the department to conduct an enquiry into the private affairs of the respondent.

questions_and_answers.question: What is Section 29 of the Police Act?
questions_and_answers.answer: Section 29 of the Police Act mandates that all police officers on duty, in their dealings with the public, shall exhibit courtesy, propriety, and compassion appropriate to the occasion and use polite and decent language.

questions_and_answers.question: What legal principle did the Court rely on to decide the case?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Court relied on Section 101(8) of the Police Act to decide the case. The Court held that when a police servant is involved in a criminal case, he cannot be proceeded against by the department on the same set of facts in the departmental proceeding once he is acquitted from the criminal case.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the respondent’s contention in OP(KAT) NO. 314 OF 2019?
questions_and_answers.answer: The respondent’s contention was that the departmental proceedings were initiated against him on two sets of allegations: firstly, with reference to the criminal offence, and secondly, with reference to the illicit relationship with the first accused, Radha. The counsel argued that no court had found that the respondent had an illicit relationship with the accused lady and since he was acquitted of the criminal charge, therefore, the departmental proceedings should be dropped against him as well.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the Court observe in Joseph Shine v. Union of India?
questions_and_answers.answer: In Joseph Shine v. Union of India, the Court observed that autonomy to fulfill sexual desires in pursuit of happiness is intrinsic to dignify human existence and the constitutional courts will have to recognize freedom of choice in sexual matters. The Court further observed that social, cultural, moral, economic, and political values may undergo change from time to time.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the objective of the departmental proceedings according to the Court’s observation?
questions_and_answers.answer: The objective of the departmental proceedings and the objective of criminal proceedings are distinct and different. The court held that an exception has been created in the Police Act whereby a police servant cannot be proceeded against by the department on the same set of facts in the departmental proceedings once he is acquitted from the criminal case. After considering Section 101(8) of Police Act, in Vijayakumar's exception case (supra), it was held that when there are materials to hold that the facts proved against the delinquent in the departmental enquiry are different from the facts proved in the criminal trial, which exonerated him.

questions_and_answers.question: What are the key takeaways from the case?
questions_and_answers.answer: The key takeaways from this case are that the Government is not supposed to enquire into the private affairs of a Government servant unless any manifest misconduct is expressed in such activities, warranting action. Secondly, when a police servant is involved in a criminal case, he cannot be proceeded against by the department on the same set of facts in the departmental proceeding once he is acquitted from the criminal case. The objective of the departmental proceedings and the objective of criminal proceedings are distinct and different.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the exception that has been craved out in the Police Act?
questions_and_answers.answer: The exception that has been craved out in the Police Act is that when a police servant is involved in a criminal case, he cannot be proceeded against by the department on the same set of facts in the departmental proceeding once he is acquitted from the criminal case.

case_title: State of Kerala vs P.K.Radhakrishnan

questions_and_answers.question: What was the issue being considered in case OP(KAT) NO.418 OF 2019?
questions_and_answers.answer: The issue being considered in case OP(KAT) NO.418 OF 2019 was whether in disciplinary proceedings initiated under the Kerala Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules, a recovery can be effected without giving the Government servant a fullest opportunity to discredit the evidence brought against him and whether proceedings can continue for the recovery of loss after the retirement of the Government servant.

questions_and_answers.question: What is Rule 15 of KCS (CC&A) Rules?
questions_and_answers.answer: Rule 15 of KCS (CC&A) Rules is the procedure for imposing major penalty. It was initially invoked in this case for disciplinary proceedings against P.K.Radhakrishnan.

questions_and_answers.question: What is Rule 16 of KCS (CC&A) Rules?
questions_and_answers.answer: Rule 16 of KCS (CC&A) Rules relates to the procedure for imposing minor penalties.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the tribunal note with regards to the conversion of proceedings from major penalty to minor penalty?
questions_and_answers.answer: The tribunal noted that converting the proceedings midway from major penalty to minor penalty was legally unsustainable and a consequent order of recovery was set aside. It was held that the procedure under Rule 15 of KCS (CC&A) Rules was not followed for effecting recovery.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the principle of natural justice?
questions_and_answers.answer: The principle of natural justice implies a fair opportunity to contradict and to obviate the prejudice that may cause to the aggrieved consequent upon the denial of such opportunity. Even in a proceedings under Rule 16 of KCS (CC&A) Rules, full and fair opportunity should be given to the respondent to discredit the materials against him.

questions_and_answers.question: What were the directions given to the petitioner-Government by the court in OP(KAT) NO.418 OF 2019?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court directed the petitioner-Government to proceed with the proceedings in accordance with the Kerala Service Rules, reserve the right of withholding or withdrawing a pension or any part of it, and the right of ordering the recovery from a pension or the whole or part of any pecuniary loss caused to Government, if in a departmental or judicial proceeding, the pensioner is found guilty of grave misconduct or negligence during the period of his service including service rendered upon re-employment after retirement. The government shall be given all the details and the materials collected against the respondent to discredit such materials. The government shall release the admitted pensionary amounts and other benefits within two months.

questions_and_answers.question: What are some of the exhibits filed by the petitioner in OP(KAT) NO.418 OF 2019?
questions_and_answers.answer: Some of the exhibits filed by the petitioner in OP(KAT) NO.418 OF 2019 include true copy of the O.A.No.2285/13 along with exhibits before the Kerala Administrative Tribunal, memo of charges issued by the Director of Agriculture, explanation submitted by the applicant, order of the Agriculture Director appointing enquiry officer, show cause notice issued by the Director of Agriculture, the claims statement, and enquiry report.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the reason for initiating disciplinary proceedings against P.K.Radhakrishnan?
questions_and_answers.answer: The disciplinary proceedings were initiated against P.K.Radhakrishnan for sustained losses in the Agricultural Department on account of the irregularities committed by him in the performance of his official duties.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the order issued against P.K.Radhakrishnan midway through the proceedings?
questions_and_answers.answer: Midway through the proceedings, the order for imposing major penalty was converted to one under Rule 16 for imposing minor penalties and ordering recovery of loss. No opportunity was given to the respondent to discredit the materials against him.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the tribunal note with regards to the continuation of proceedings for recovery of loss?
questions_and_answers.answer: The tribunal noted that the continuation of proceedings for recovery of loss after the retirement of the Government servant under Rule 16 of KCS (CC&A) Rules would not be legally sustainable without following the procedure under Rule 15 of KCS (CC&A) Rules for effecting recovery.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the court direct the petitioner-Government to do after OP(KAT) NO.418 OF 2019 was concluded?
questions_and_answers.answer: After OP(KAT) NO.418 OF 2019 was concluded, the court directed the petitioner-Government to release the admitted pensionary amounts and other benefits within two months.

questions_and_answers.question: How long was the petitioner-Government given to conclude the proceedings as per the court's directions in OP(KAT) NO.418 OF 2019?
questions_and_answers.answer: The petitioner-Government was given three months to conclude the proceedings as per the court's directions in OP(KAT) NO.418 OF 2019.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the court note with regards to the principles of natural justice in disciplinary proceedings?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court noted that the principles of natural justice should be read into the statutory provisions of the disciplinary proceedings. Full and fair opportunity should be given to the respondent to discredit the materials collected which are relied on for fastening the liability. If the recovery of loss is effected without giving an opportunity of hearing to the respondent to discredit the materials, such proceedings will be vitiated.

questions_and_answers.question: Under which Kerala Service Rule were the proceedings initiated in the case State of Kerala vs P.K.Radhakrishnan?
questions_and_answers.answer: The proceedings were initiated under Rule 15 of KCS (CC&A) Rules and Rule 3 part III of the Kerala Service Rules.

questions_and_answers.question: What will happen if a pensioner is found guilty of grave misconduct or negligence during the period of his service in accordance with Rule 3 of the KSR?
questions_and_answers.answer: If a pensioner is found guilty of grave misconduct or negligence during the period of his service in accordance with Rule 3 of the KSR, the government may reserve the right of withholding or withdrawing a pension or any part of it, whether permanently or for a specified period and may also order the recovery from a pension or the whole or part of any pecuniary loss caused to Government.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the famous principle enunciated by Lord Denning with regards to the right to be heard?
questions_and_answers.answer: Lord Denning in B.Surinder Singh Kanda v. Government of the Federation of Malaya (1962 AC 322) observed that if the right to be heard is to be a real right which is worth anything, it must carry with it a right in the accused man to know the case which is made against him. He must know what evidence has been given and what statements have been made affecting him and then he must be given a fair opportunity to correct or contradict them.

questions_and_answers.question: What will happen if recovery of loss is effected without giving an opportunity of hearing to the respondent to discredit the materials?
questions_and_answers.answer: If the recovery of loss is effected without giving an opportunity of hearing to the respondent to discredit the materials collected which are relied on for fastening the liability, such proceedings will be vitiated on the principle of natural justice. The principles of natural justice will have to be read into the statutory provisions of the disciplinary proceedings.

questions_and_answers.question: What were the consequences of converting the proceedings from major penalty to minor penalty midway according to the tribunal?
questions_and_answers.answer: According to the tribunal, converting the proceedings from major penalty to minor penalty midway was legally unsustainable. A consequent order of recovery was set aside and the procedure under Rule 15 of KCS (CC&A) Rules was not followed for effecting recovery. Hence, full and fair opportunity should be given to the respondent to discredit the materials against him even in a proceedings under Rule 16 of KCS (CC&A) Rules.

questions_and_answers.answer: Exhibit P2 filed by the petitioner in OP(KAT) NO.418 OF 2019 was a true copy of the interim order dated 18.10.2013.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the reason for Dr. Athira P. and Dr. Arya G. Krishnan approaching the Kerala Administrative Tribunal?
questions_and_answers.answer: Dr. Athira P. and Dr. Arya G. Krishnan approached the Kerala Administrative Tribunal as they were aggrieved by the rejection of their candidature. They had argued that they must be deemed to have continuous service in terms of Government Order dated 19.05.2021, and hence be given preferential appointments to the post of Assistant Surgeon/Emergency Medical Officer.

questions_and_answers.question: What were the main legal issues considered in this case?
questions_and_answers.answer: The main legal issues considered in this case were the concept of substantive equality in employment, maternity benefits under the Indian Constitution, Article 16 (1) of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW), and whether discrimination against women on the grounds of maternity is unconstitutional.

questions_and_answers.question: What were the criteria set for promotion to the post of Assistant Surgeon/Emergency Medical Officer?
questions_and_answers.answer: The criteria set for promotion to the post of Assistant Surgeon/Emergency Medical Officer were as follows: MBBS degree, Post Graduate Degree/Diploma in the respective specialty, registration with the Indian Medical Council, and women without any interruptions in service.

questions_and_answers.question: What is substantive equality?
questions_and_answers.answer: Substantive equality is a concept in employment that focuses on creating space to remove gender attributes' barriers and accommodate differences. The principle of substantive equality includes four dimensions: redress disadvantage, address stigma, enhance voice and participation, and accommodate differences to achieve structural change.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the final verdict in OP(KAT) No. 507 of 2023?
questions_and_answers.answer: The final verdict in OP(KAT) No. 507 of 2023 was in favor of Dr. Athira P., who was seeking to be appointed as an Assistant Surgeon/Emergency Medical Officer. The court held that maternity period be treated as continuous service, and directed the respondents to consider the petitioners' claims for appointment to the post of Assistant Surgeon/Emergency Medical Officer.

questions_and_answers.question: What is institutional and systemic discrimination?
questions_and_answers.answer: Institutional discrimination refers to practices that create unequal opportunities for particular groups in a given organization or institution, such as employment policies that exclude certain groups from consideration for certain positions. Systemic discrimination involves practices and systems in society that exclude or discriminate against certain groups.

questions_and_answers.question: What were the legal principles applied in this case?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court applied multiple legal principles in this case, including Article 14 of the Indian Constitution, CEDAW Article 16 (1), and substantive equality. The court also referred to previous judgments in Ravinder Kumar Dhariwal v. Union of India and Joseph Shine v. Union of India.

questions_and_answers.question: What are the rights concerning non-discrimination on marriage and maternity in CEDAW Article 11?
questions_and_answers.answer: CEDAW Article 11 advocates for non-discrimination against women on the grounds of marriage or maternity. The article requires states parties to take appropriate measures to prevent discrimination on those grounds and ensure that women have equal rights to decide freely and responsibly on the number and spacing of their children and access to education on sexual and reproductive health.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the aim of substantive equality?
questions_and_answers.answer: The aim of substantive equality is to create a social context where the right to equality is responsive to the needs of those who have been disadvantaged, demeaned, excluded, or ignored because of their status. It is a principle that seeks to remove barriers and promote differences in order to redress disadvantage, address stigma, enhance voice and participation, and achieve structural change.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the importance of substantial equality in public employment?
questions_and_answers.answer: Substantial equality is significant in public employment because it helps to create equal opportunities and eliminate discriminatory policies and practices. It ensures that women are not discriminated against on the grounds of their gender or maternity status and that their rights and dignity are protected.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the court's opinion on motherhood in Mini v. Life Insurance Corporation of India?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court in Mini v. Life Insurance Corporation of India deliberated on whether motherhood is integral to the dignity of women or not and held that motherhood is crucial to a woman's dignity and status. The court also stated that motherhood must not be a disadvantage in society and women must be given equal opportunities to work.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the significance of Article 16 of the Indian Constitution?
questions_and_answers.answer: Article 16 of the Indian Constitution requires the state to eliminate all forms of discrimination against women in matters related to marriage and family relations, and to ensure that they have equal rights in decision-making concerning family planning and access to sexual and reproductive health education.

questions_and_answers.question: What dimensions does substantive equality include?
questions_and_answers.answer: Substantive equality includes four essential dimensions: redress disadvantage, address stigma, enhance voice and participation, and accommodate differences to achieve structural change. Each of these dimensions enables society to remove barriers and ensure that all individuals have equal opportunities and access to employment and other opportunities.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the court's opinion on direct and indirect discrimination?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court recognized both direct and indirect discrimination. Direct discrimination refers to discriminatory practices that are explicitly stated, while indirect discrimination refers to policies and practices that are not explicitly discriminatory but result in exclusion or unequal treatment of certain groups.

questions_and_answers.question: What does CEDAW Article 11 state?
questions_and_answers.answer: CEDAW Article 11 prohibits discrimination against women on the grounds of marriage or maternity and aims to ensure that women have equal access to work opportunities and that they have the right to decide freely and responsibly on the number and spacing of their children.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the respondents' argument in OP(KAT) No. 507 of 2023?

Krishnan for preferential treatment in public employment. questions_and_answers.question: What is the purpose of Article 14 of the Indian Constitution?
questions_and_answers.answer: Article 14 of the Indian Constitution aims to prevent discrimination against individuals and provides for equality before the law and equal protection under the law. It ensures that every individual is treated fairly and equally, without any distinction based on caste, creed, religion, gender, or any other status or attribute.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the court hold regarding maternity benefits under the Indian Constitution in OP(KAT) No. 507 of 2023?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court held that maternity benefits under the Indian Constitution must be interpreted broadly and in line with the Government Order dated 19.05.2021. This means that maternity period must be treated as continuous service, and women must be given preferential treatment in public employment to redress historical disadvantages caused by gender-based discrimination.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the relevance of the Indian Constitution in public employment?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Indian Constitution provides for the right to equality and non-discrimination in public employment. This means that all individuals must have equal opportunities to work and access to public employment without any discrimination on the grounds of caste, gender, religion, or any other status or attribute. The Constitution also provides for affirmative action to promote the interests of disadvantaged groups.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the court's opinion on substantive equality in employment?

questions_and_answers.question: What was the final verdict in OP(KAT) No. 521 of 2023?

questions_and_answers.question: What is indirect discrimination?
questions_and_answers.answer: Indirect discrimination occurs when policies or practices appear neutral but result in the exclusion or adverse effect on particular groups. questions_and_answers.question: What is the relevance of CEDAW Article 16 (1) in this case?

questions_and_answers.question: What is the significance of the Indian Constitution in public employment?

questions_and_answers.question: What grounds were raised for challenging the maintainability of Section 12(1) of the Act by the tenant?

questions_and_answers.question: What legal principle was relied on by the learned counsel for the tenant to support their contention?
questions_and_answers.answer: He relied on the decision of this court in Sadique v. Mohammed Umair, 2017 (3) KLT 759, in support of the said contention.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the contention of the learned counsel for the tenant in the case relied on by them?
questions_and_answers.answer: Where a tenant denies the title of the landlord within the meaning of the second proviso to Section 11(1) of the Act, unless and until the question whether the denial of title is bona fide or not, is decided by the court, no application under Section 12(1) of the Act can be entertained.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the basis of the contention of the tenant in case RCREV. NO. 46 OF 2023?

questions_and_answers.question: What does the court say about the contention raised by the learned counsel for the tenant in case RCREV. NO. 46 OF 2023?
questions_and_answers.answer: The learned counsel has also contended that at any rate, insofar as the tenant has disputed the title of the landlord, an application under Section 12 should not have been entertained by the Rent Control Court before the question as to whether the dispute as to the title raised by the tenant is bona fide, is decided by the Rent Control Court. The court does not find that this argument applies in this case.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the settled law regarding transfer of property subject to pending proceedings?
questions_and_answers.answer: It is settled law that a transfer which is made lis pendens is not a void transaction. It does create rights as between the parties to the transfer, but of course subject to the final outcome of the lis.

questions_and_answers.question: What position is taken by the court in relation to transfer of property subject to pending proceedings in RCREV. NO. 46 OF 2023?
questions_and_answers.answer: If that be the position, according to us, the landlord who transfers the building subject to the lis, and nevertheless continues the proceedings, is certainly entitled to prefer an application under Section 12(1), and the said application cannot be said to be not maintainable.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the main legal principle applied in case RCREV. NO. 46 OF 2023?
questions_and_answers.answer: The main legal principle applied was that a landlord, who transfers the building subject to the lis, and nevertheless continues the proceedings, is entitled to prefer an application under Section 12(1), and the said application cannot be said to be not maintainable.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the decision of the court in case RCREV. NO. 46 OF 2023?

questions_and_answers.question: What did the court say about the jurisdiction of the Rent Controller?

questions_and_answers.question: What presumption is available under Section 90 of Indian Evidence Act?
questions_and_answers.answer: Section 90 of the Indian Evidence Act gives rise to the presumption as to the signature and its genuineness if the document is produced from proper custody.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the relevance of an ancient document according to Taylor's The Law of Evidence?
questions_and_answers.answer: An ancient document, i.e., more than thirty years old, often furnishes the only attainable evidence of ancient possession. The law, on the principle of necessity, allows them to be read in courts of justice on behalf and against persons in no way privy to them, provided that they are not mere narratives of past events, but that they purport to have formed a part of the act of ownership, exercise of right, or other transaction to which they relate.

questions_and_answers.question: What happens if there are no materials to hold the relationship between landlord and tenants?
questions_and_answers.answer: If there are no materials to hold the relationship between the landlord and tenant further, an enquiry on title is warranted under the Act. If the enquiry conducted by the Rent Controller satisfies the existence of jural relationship of the landlord and the tenant, the tenant would be estopped from raising the further claim of the permanent tenancy or to raise a dispute on the title of the landlord.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the definition of 'landlord' and 'tenant' under Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act, 1965?
questions_and_answers.answer: As per Section 2(6)(i) of the Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act, 1965, tenant means any person by whom or on whose account, rent is payable for a building and includes an heir or heirs of the deceased tenant.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the scope of enquiry and qua competency of the Rent Controller?

questions_and_answers.question: What are the relevant page numbers regarding the issue of jurisdiction in RCREV.NO.82 of 2022?

questions_and_answers.question: What is the role of Section 90 of the Indian Evidence Act in RCREV.NO.82 of 2022?

questions_and_answers.question: What presumption arises under the Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act, 1965 if a person is in possession of a building as a tenant?

questions_and_answers.question: What is the relevance of Section 11(4)(iv) of the Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act, 1965 in RCP No.6/2016?

case_title: LALU MATHEW vs BINO ALEXANDER

questions_and_answers.question: Who is the petitioner and respondent in RCREV.NO. 104 OF 2023?
questions_and_answers.answer: Lalu Mathew is the petitioner and Bino Alexander is the respondent in RCREV.NO. 104 OF 2023.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the tenancy arrangement referred to in RCREV.NO. 104 OF 2023?
questions_and_answers.answer: The tenancy arrangement referred to in RCREV.NO. 104 OF 2023 is the portion of the ground floor of a three storeyed building measuring 750 sq.ft. which is being used by the tenant as a showroom for his crockery business.

questions_and_answers.question: What order did the Rent Control Court pass in this case?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Rent Control Court ordered eviction in this case.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the contention raised by the tenant before the Rent Control Court?
questions_and_answers.answer: One of the contentions raised by the tenant in the proceedings was that the need set out by the landlord is not bona fide, and it is after rejecting the said contention, eviction was ordered by the Rent Control Court.

questions_and_answers.question: What happened when the first floor of the building, measuring approximately 1800 sq.ft., became vacant during the pendency of this case?
questions_and_answers.answer: During the pendency of this case, the first floor of the building, measuring approximately 1800 sq.ft., held by another tenant of the landlord fell vacant, and the tenant preferred an interlocutory application then in the appeal seeking orders appointing an Advocate Commissioner to ascertain and report the said fact. The said application was rejected by the Appellate Authority. The tenant challenged the order passed by the Appellate Authority in this regard before this Court in O.P. (RC) No.17 of 2022. This Court dismissed the above original petition holding that it is unnecessary to appoint an Advocate Commissioner for the purpose sought for, as there is no dispute as regards the said fact.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision of the Appellate Authority in this case?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Appellate Authority affirmed the decision of the Rent Control Court, and the tenant was aggrieved by the said decision of the Appellate Authority and preferred this revision petition.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the contention of the tenant before the court in RCREV.NO. 104 OF 2023?
questions_and_answers.answer: The contention of the tenant before the court in RCREV.NO. 104 OF 2023 was that the Appellate Authority ought to have considered the issue whether the fact that the first floor of the building which fell vacant during the pendency of the appeal has any impact on the relief claimed by the landlord.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the proposition canvassed by the tenant's learned counsel before the court in this case?
questions_and_answers.answer: The proposition canvassed by the learned counsel of the tenant before the court in this case was that in cases where a landlord has another building of his own in his possession in the same city, if the landlord has to seek an order of eviction against a tenant on the ground of personal requirement, the provisions of Section 11(3) of the Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act should be interpreted in the light of the judgments of Hasmat Rai and Sheshambal of the Apex Court.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the court state about the first proviso to Section 11(3) of the Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court stated that the first proviso to Section 11(3) of the Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act can be pressed into service in cases where a landlord obtains another building after the institution of the eviction petition and that the said proviso is applicable as long as the need for eviction remains intact.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the court observe about the subsequent events that occur during the progress and passage of legal proceedings from court to court?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court observed that it cannot ignore subsequent events that occur during the progress of legal proceedings and that if such events occur, the court has to examine and evaluate the same and mould the relief accordingly, so that the relief is tailored to the situation that obtains on the date the relief is actually granted.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the court observe about the right of a party to obtain relief in legal proceedings?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court observed that it is fundamental that the right of a party to obtain relief in legal proceedings is one to be determined with reference to the date of institution of the proceedings, and for making the right or remedy claimed by the party just and meaningful as also legally and factually in accord with the current realities, the court can, and in many cases must, take cautious cognizance of events and developments subsequent to the institution of the proceedings provided the rules of fairness to both sides are scrupulously obeyed.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the contention of the tenant's counsel with respect to Section 11(3) of the Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act?
questions_and_answers.answer: The learned counsel for the tenant contended that if the landlord has another building of his own in his possession in the same city, and if he has to seek an order of eviction against a tenant on the ground of personal requirement, without disclosing the need or requirement, in order to eclipse the bona fides of the need or requirement, the landlord should surrender the said building in his possession to the tenant cancelling the tenancy, so that there will be an end to the dispute between them regarding the said premises.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the contention of the landlord's counsel with respect to Section 11(3) of the Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act?
questions_and_answers.answer: The learned counsel for the landlord contended that once the Rent Control Court or the first appellate court has found that the requirement pleaded by the landlord for the disputed building is bona fide, there is no further hurdle for the eviction order that has been passed to stand.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision of the court in RCREV.NO. 104 OF 2023?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court, in RCREV.NO. 104 OF 2023, held that the provisions of Section 11(3) of the Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act are not overridden or repelled in any manner by any other provision of the statute and that the first proviso to the section can be pressed into service even in cases where the landlord obtains another building after the institution of the eviction petition.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the court observe about the interpretation of a statute?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court observed that the general rule of interpretation of a statute is that the words of a statute must prima facie be given their ordinary and natural meaning, and that this rule of construction is subject to an exception that where such construction leads to an anomaly, absurdity, hardship, injustice or mischief, the Court may resort to other rules to interpret the statute.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the court observe about the limited scope of its jurisdiction in a revision petition?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court observed that in a revision petition, it has only a limited scope of adjudication, and that it is not inclined to re-appreciate the evidence and re-write the judgment delivered by the subordinate courts below.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the impact of the subsequent event of the landlord obtaining possession of another building on the order of eviction?
questions_and_answers.answer: In RCREV.NO. 104 OF 2023, the court observed that the subsequent event of the landlord obtaining possession of another building did not have any impact on the order of eviction passed against the tenant.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the court state about the arguments of the tenant's counsel regarding the first proviso to Section 11(3) of the Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court stated that the arguments of the tenant's counsel were more in the nature of academic exercises than anything else, and they had no bearing on the facts of the case in hand. The court further observed that the contention raised by the landlord that the need for the disputed premises exists even after the first floor of the building fell vacant was a valid one, and the same has been accepted by both the Rent Control Court and the Appellate Authority.

questions_and_answers.question: What is Section 11(3) of the Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act?
questions_and_answers.answer: Section 11(3) of the Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act is a provision that precludes the Rent Control Court from granting an order of eviction unless it is satisfied that it is just and proper to do so for special reasons. The first proviso to the section provides that an order of eviction passed in pursuance of clause (c) of sub-section (1) of Section 11 shall not be executed before the expiry of one year from the date of passing the order.

questions_and_answers.question: What were the decisions relied on by the tenant's counsel in this case?
questions_and_answers.answer: The decisions relied on by the tenant's counsel in this case were Hasmat Rai and Sheshambal of the Apex Court, which were said to lay down a proposition that in cases where a landlord has another building of his own in his possession in the same city, if he has to seek an order of eviction against a tenant on the ground of personal requirement, the provisions of Section 11(3) of the Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act should be interpreted.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the contention of the tenant regarding the impugned orders?

questions_and_answers.question: What was the decision of the appellate court?

questions_and_answers.question: What did the learned senior counsel for the tenant contend?
questions_and_answers.answer: The learned senior counsel for the tenant contended that an order of interlocutory nature is appealable under section 18 of the Act.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the learned counsel for the respondent rely on?
questions_and_answers.answer: The learned counsel for the respondent relied on the judgments in Thankamony Amma v. Omana Amma [2019 (4) KLT 361 (SC)]; Addissery Raghavan v. Cheruvalath Krishnadasan [2020 (3) KLT 605 (SC)]; Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Ltd. v. Dilbahar Singh [2014 (4) KLT 182 (SC)], which deal with the scope of revisional jurisdiction of the High Court while entertaining a revision.

questions_and_answers.question: What case laws did the petitioner rely on for support of their contentions?
questions_and_answers.answer: The petitioner relied on case laws including the judgments in State of Kerala, K.S. Das v. [1992 (2) KLT 358(LB)]; Thomas v. George [1988 KLT 18]; and Punjab National Bank and others [(2007) 2 SCC 230]

questions_and_answers.question: What is Section 23(1) of the Act?
questions_and_answers.answer: Section 23(1) of the Act specifies the powers which are vested in a court under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908) when trying a suit in respect of various matters.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the conclusion of the court regarding section 23(1) of the Act?
questions_and_answers.answer: On perusal of Section 23(1) of the Act, the court noted that there is no specific provision for correcting the mistakes in the rent control petition. However, Section 23(1)(j) of the Act discusses the power to amend any defect or error in orders or proceedings.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the court conclude regarding the maintainability of the revision petition?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court held that the impugned orders were interlocutory orders that would not affect the rights of the tenant and could have been agitated during the trial. Therefore, the court held that the revision petitions were not maintainable.

questions_and_answers.question: What other provision besides Section 18 is relevant in this case?
questions_and_answers.answer: Another relevant provision in this case is Section 23(1) of the Act, which specifies the powers of the Rent Control Court and the Appellate Authority when trying a suit.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the significance of the judgment in K.S.Das v. State of Kerala?
questions_and_answers.answer: K.S.Das v. State of Kerala discusses the maintainability of an appeal against an interlocutory order provided it is a final order on the miscellaneous petitions, substantial affects the rights of the parties, and are matters of moment or which would cause real legal prejudice to the parties, even though the parent original proceeding is alive.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the significance of the judgment in Thomas v. George?
questions_and_answers.answer: Thomas v. George discussed the expression of meantime, interim or ad interim, or stages and how it should be understood.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the significance of the judgment in Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Ltd. v. Dilbahar Singh?
questions_and_answers.answer: Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Ltd. v. Dilbahar Singh discussed the concept of 'finality' in regards to section 18 of the Act.

questions_and_answers.question: What general principles were applied in this case?
questions_and_answers.answer: Some of the general principles applied in this case were the interpretation of Section 18 of the Act, the maintainability of appeals, and the distinction between interlocutory orders and final orders.

questions_and_answers.answer: The petitioner in RCREV.NO.137 of 2023 challenged the decision of the Rent Control Court to reject her plea of denial of title to the property in question.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the outcome of RCP No. 4 of 2019?

questions_and_answers.question: What is the Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act?

questions_and_answers.question: What is res judicata?
questions_and_answers.answer: Res judicata is a Latin term meaning 'a matter already judged.' In legal terms, it refers to the principle that a matter that has been finally decided by a competent court between the same parties cannot be re-agitated in another court or proceedings, except as provided by law.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the Limitation Act?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Limitation Act is a law in India that prescribes a limit on the time period within which a legal action can be brought forward. It aims to ensure that legal disputes are resolved within a reasonable time, so that parties can move on without undue delay.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the legal consequence of not challenging an appealable order on time?
questions_and_answers.answer: If a party to litigation does not challenge an appealable order on time, the same is considered final, and the party cannot challenge the order afterward. This principle is known as the doctrine of finality of judgments.

case_title: Nithya R. Warriar vs Kendriya Vidyalaya Sangathan

questions_and_answers.question: What is the case about?
questions_and_answers.answer: The case is about the transfer of a Trained Graduate Teacher (English), who is a single mother, on promotion to the post of Post Graduate Teacher (English), to Kendriya Vidyalaya-II, ONGC, Agartala, which is about 2200 km away from Kochi. The petitioner challenged the transfer on the grounds that being a single parent, she has to take care of her minor child and is worried of violation of visitorial rights granted to the father if she is transferred to a distant place.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the Central Administrative Tribunal (CAT) order after hearing the case?
questions_and_answers.answer: After elaborate consideration of the issue, the Tribunal directed the authorities concerned to consider the matter afresh and to consider whether the petitioner can be posted in Kerala or any other convenient place in any neighboring State.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the argument made by the learned Central Government Counsel to challenge the petitioner's claim?
questions_and_answers.answer: The learned Central Government Counsel submitted that the applicant did not join in the promoted post and refused to accept the promotion offered and thus, she has forfeited her right, pursuant to which, the offer of promotion had been withdrawn. The court disagreed with this argument.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the observation made by the court on being a single mother?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court observed that being a single mother is not an easy task; handling two times the stress and work, giving out two times the love, navigating life’s challenges with grace. Sometimes, the strength of motherhood is greater than natural laws.

questions_and_answers.question: What are visitorial rights?
questions_and_answers.answer: Visitorial rights are the rights granted to a parent to have a say in the upbringing of their child or to visit their child, especially after divorce or separation.

questions_and_answers.question: What did the court say about the child's rights in this case?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court held that it's not only the matter of posting of the employee/mother of the child, but the rights of the child also come into play and the rights of the child cannot be pressed into a situation like this where the litigation is essentially leading to the promotion and posting of the mother of the child.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the direction given by the Tribunal to the authorities concerned?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Tribunal directed the authorities concerned to consider the matter afresh and to consider whether the petitioner can be posted in Kerala or any other convenient place in any neighboring State.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the argument made by the learned counsel for the Union of India?
questions_and_answers.answer: The learned counsel for the Union of India argued that the modification of the list was done as regards the teachers who have already joined the place wherein they were promoted, and hence, the petitioner did not get the posting in Kerala.

questions_and_answers.question: What is Annex.A21?
questions_and_answers.answer: Annex.A21 is a representation submitted by the petitioner to the 1st respondent requesting to cancel the transfer order to KV ONGC, Agartala and to consider her for a posting within Kerala or in the nearby Kendriya Vidyalayas.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the final judgment of the court?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court dismissed the original petition and upheld the order of the Central Administrative Tribunal, directing the authorities concerned to consider the matter afresh, and to consider whether the petitioner can be posted in Kerala or any other convenient place in any neighboring State.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the court's opinion on the State authorities' behavior?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court observed that if the State authorities themselves proactively adopt a compassionate perspective in a case of this nature, there may not be any necessity for the court to always urge or admonish the State authorities to behave in a proportionate and reasonable manner in matters affecting fundamental rights.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the reason for rejecting the argument of learned counsel for the Union of India?
questions_and_answers.answer: The court rejected the argument of learned counsel for the Union of India that the petitioner did not get the posting in Kerala because modification of the list was done as regards the teachers who have already joined the place wherein they were promoted, and instead observed that the transfer order violated the petitioner's fundamental rights as well as the visitorial rights of the child's father.

case_title: B.SURESH vs UNION OF INDIA

questions_and_answers.question: What is OP (CAT) No. 54 of 2023?
questions_and_answers.answer: OP (CAT) No. 54 of 2023 is a case filed by B. Suresh against Union of India, the Chief Engineer & Administrator, Andaman Lakshadweep Harbour Works and other respondents, in the Kerala High Court, challenging the Tribunal's order in OA No. 131 of 2020.

questions_and_answers.question: Who is B. Suresh?
questions_and_answers.answer: B. Suresh is the petitioner in OP (CAT) No. 54 of 2023. He was the driver in the Andaman Lakshadweep Harbour Works, who was originally appointed as a temporary driver on an ad hoc basis on 28.05.1984.

questions_and_answers.question: What was the order passed by the Central Administrative Tribunal, Ernakulam Bench, challenged by B. Suresh?
